Yes, I am. Take care you give him no encouragement, d'ye hear girl? No whiſperings from your balcony; no private correſpondences;
no billets dropt by your officious maid, on pretence they are meant for ſome carotty-pated country couſin!

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Dear Sir!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: No pencil'd aſſignations on the back of your fan; or cards in lemon juice—to be call'd on detection ſecret orders to your perfumer, for pearl powder, and bloom of Circaſſia.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: How can you put ſuch things in the girl's head, deary?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: (aſide) That her fingers may put them in practice, to be ſure; but you are not up to me there, deary! (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: But a few minutes ſince, you were fearful, Sir, that he was not received with ſufficient favour.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: That was—that—well, no matter. That was, perhaps, to try how far things had gone.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Oh I beg your pardon! the curtain riſes, and we ſee the ſun! Now I underſtand your policy—how admirable! You middle-aged gentlemen are ſo deep, that 'tis difficult to ſift ye.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Ay, and when we are ſifted—

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: You are found to be chaff. Poor dear Don Octavio! Send him a garland of willows, Viola.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Rather of myrtles—he's too handſome for willows.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Handſome is he, that handſome does— remember that.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Why Sir, he does handſomely. He has travell'd handſomely, has a handſome eſtate, has brought home a handſome character, and now wiſhes for a handſome wife.

sp.speaker: Alex,
sp.p: Ay, but he muſt go further a field to catch her though. He'll find neither wives nor widgeons in my orchard.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: No, our widgeons are all within doors.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Unfortunate that I am! juſt made up my mind to diſmiſs Sebaſtian, nay abſolutely to diſlike him, and now—

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: And now! why now you muſt make up your mind t'other way. Perhaps in my preſent humour, of the two fools, I like Sebaſtian beſt.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: But that humour muſt change, for I can never think of thoſe two young men as you do, my dear father.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Thoughts are free, daughter! Gad I could hug her. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: You ſee your father generouſly leaves your thoughts unſhackled, my dear; he only deſires to controul your actions—pray oblige him, and take Sebaſtian.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: (aſide) Zounds! ſhe knows nothing of our plot, and gives that advice ſeriouſly.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: He is a moſt accompliſh'd young man.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Wiſe!

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Engaging in his manners, and reſiſtleſs in his form.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: My dear, I ſay. (ſpitefully.)

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: His eyes are expreſſive, and his tongue is eloquent.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: The devil's in your tongue! (aſide.) You don't know what you are talking of.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: I do indeed—perfectly. In ſhort, Viola, he is ſo amiable, ſo captivating, and loves you with ſuch unbounded fondneſs, that if you marry any other, your miſery ought to equal your ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Gad ſhe ſpeaks with an air of too much conviction—this muſt be managed more nicely. To your chamber, huſſey, and try to forget Octavio.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: And remember your Sebaſtian. Let him be preſent to you waking, and ſleeping; let him—

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Zounds let him alone! (driving her off on the other ſide) you may be doing miſchief all this while. I dare not let her into my plot, leſt her perverſeneſs, or her folly ſhould mar it. And yet, I think—no hang it I won't—I won't. The only plot that ever had a woman in it came to nothing. I'll conduct this ſolely by my own ſagacity, and have a hearty laugh at the poor fools, when all is over.

div.head: SCENE, An elegant Apartment at Don Gaſper's, illuminated.
div.stage: Rachel enters firſt; followed by Gaſper, Antonia, Clara, and a number of Ladies.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: (looking back) Bleſs us! the approach of the ceremony has made my maſter half out of his ſenſes. The poor bride too ſeems half out of her's—but not with joy—if I may gueſs.

sp.speaker: Don Gaſp.
sp.l: Tired of dance, of ſong, and play,
sp.p: Yes, yes, now for the ceremony! Come my pretty Pet, the Prieſt is waiting in the next room to make thee the happieſt girl in Portugal. In ten minutes thou wilt be the wife of Don. Gaſper de Frontado! (ſtrutting.)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: (Aſide) Oh heaven! where is Henry? Rachel, my ſoul ſinks within me.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Truly, mine is not very high.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Heyday! what's all this about? What! ſhe muſt be coax'd now I warrant—they all love coaxing. Come now, my pretty Tony, my nown little Tony. (Taking her under his arm.)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: (breaking from him) Henry! Henry! Where art thou? Oh, he mocks me!

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Come, let us to the prieſt, and tie the knot, which even Alexander who cut the gordion will never be able to deſtroy.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: (without.) Where is he—the bridegroom! the happy bridegroom!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Oh my heart—he is come!

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Here he is—here is the happy bridegroom. (Henry enters) Come, you are juſt in time to witneſs the ceremony.—The prieſt waits to join us in his roſy bands. Look at her! h-u-m! Oh, you ſweet little—There are ſmiles and bluſhes for ye! Look at her!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: They are like thoſe of Aurora, when ſhe ſlies before the jolly god of day!

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: And I the jolly god of day purſue her.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: But charming Antonia, the bliſsful fate which awaits you muſt be poſtponed a few hours. Oh, Sir, I am ſent—

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Sent—about what! from whom?—who has ſent you to poſtpone Antonia's bliſs?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: It is happy I have a token to convince you. Here, Sir, — do you know this great ſcal ring? the impreſſion is—ſtay, can you ſee it? (taking a candle) the impreſſion is a ſatyr; look at his horns.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p:
The devil's in ſuch luck! A man on the wrong ſide of fifty or ſo, can't marry but at every turn he has horns in his teeth. If he's invited to a tavern, the dinner is ſure to be at the horns: They'll wake me with horns to-morrow morning
—nay, I am even kept from the ceremony tonight, to be regaled with the ſight of horns.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: (to Clara.) What can be the purport of the ring? I can hardly breathe thro' terror!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Do you know them, Sir?

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Know them! Yes—they are Don Alexis's horns, not mine—it is his ring; —but what have I to do with it, any more than with the ring of Saturn, or the belt of Jupiter? If you are for rings, you ſhall ſee one preſently (taking Antonia's hand) on this waxen finger, that—

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: You will not hear me, Sir. This is a token from Don Alexis—obſerve me, Sir, a token; by which you are required, as a counſellor of the realm, to meet Don Alexis immediately at his own houſe, on affairs of imminent importance.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Meet Don Alexis! What is he mad? or are you mad? or does he think me mad? Go, prithee—I'll meet him to-morrow. (ſeizing Antonia's hand) My ſervice to his night cap! (going.)

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: To-morrow! Why, all our throats may be cut by to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Hey! throats cut!

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Why Sir, there's a plot—a plot.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: A plot!

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: (to Ant.) Now I have his deſign. My dear Don Gaſper, at a juncture ſo important, every ſelfiſh conſideration muſt be annihilated. Should our diſcontented citizens take arms—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Nay, for aught I know they are in arms already.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Arms! well what can I do? Fight dog fight bear—I'll be married. (going.)

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: (dropping on her knee) Oh dear Sir, there'll be nothing but rapes and murder! Oh take pity on us poor virgins, Sir, and go.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Don't be a fool! (ſtriving to get free.)

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.p: Conſider, Sir, the good of the nation.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, the good of the nation;—what wouldn't a body do for the good of the nation?

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Good of the nation!—'twould be a ſhame! Go—go Julio, and vote for me; I'll make you my proxy.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Your proxy there, Sir! No, no, excuſe me. But haſten;—whilſt you dally, all Liſbon may be fired.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: If there's ſuch danger, I am ſafeſt here— an't I, duck? (to Ant.)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Oh Sir, if you can reſiſt the calls of honour, do not reſiſt me. To marry in the midſt of ſuch horrible apprehenſions, is impoſſible—and my fears are ſo great, they will deſtroy me. Sweet Don Gaſper, go!

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Nay then—come, my dear Nephew, let us go together; not a ſtep will I move without you.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: (aſide) Oh miſerable, to be thus circumvented. Had I not better ſtay here to guard the—

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Stay here!—Oh you are a dutiful Nephew. No, Sir, you ſhall guard me, if I ſtir—but I won't ſtir by all—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fye, Don Julio! ſurely you will not deſert your uncle. Leave him in the ſtreet, and return inſtantly! (apart) Adieu, ſweet bridegroom, (helping to get him out) ſpeed quickly back, (looking after them) but find Antonia gone! Dear liberty, I hail thee! Oh Rachel, now I claim thy promiſe; —aſſiſt my flight, and make thy terms and fortune. Follow—follow me! Exit.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: I will—but let me conſider firſt what I have engaged to do, to make my fortune. Why I am to aſſiſt a pretty girl to run away from an old huſband to a young one; from age, gout, and petulance, to youth, health, and glowing love. Ay, that I will, or may I never arrive at higher honour than to attend miſſes in their bibs, and antient maidens in their ſpectacles!

div.head: ACT V. An Apartment at Don Alexis's.
div.stage: A Table with Candles and Chairs.
He enters, followed by a Servant.

sp.speaker: Alexis.
sp.p: HEY dey! why what's the meaning of all this? The family are all up, though it is paſt twelve o'clock, and my wife's apartments in a blaze—illuminated! as though it was ſome grand anniverſary. What's the meaning of all this, I ſay?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Donna Seraphina has ladies with her, Sir—they have been playing.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Playing! go, get along and let me know when they break up. (Exit Servant.) There's no having any reſt in this world.—No, or at leaſt not for the huſbands of this world.—This cuſtom of letting one's wives receive female company, is like ſhutting your gates upon the enemy, and then helping them over the wall. Not a woman but has her head full of projects, and her pockets of billets-doux. Well, if at laſt Don Octavio ſhould really marry my daughter, I ſhall then hope—

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Don Gaſper de Frontado is without, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Don Gaſper—Don Gaſper! it can't be.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: He is indeed, Sir, attended by moſt of his ſervants, with drawn ſwords and torches.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Swords and torches—why he's mad! the near approach of matrimony has turn'd his brain. Well, no great wonder. It is Gaſper ſure enough! (looking through the wing) What a figure!—

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: (Speaking as he enters) Bleſs me, why all is quiet—all is quiet, my dear nephew! ah (looking back) what's he gone? Not a voice in the ſtreet, but two old women quarrelling about a ſtring of ſauſages.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Ay it is ſo—he's certainly crazy. I am very ſorry Don Gaſper (gravely taking off his hat) that any thing ſhould have happen'd to call you from your houſe, at this time.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: My houſe—that's nothing! From my bride—from my little Tony—from the very altar, my friend. But that is nothing—the good of the nation muſt be minded. Come let us ſit and to buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: As ſoon as you pleaſe. Zounds, what a time for him to think on the good of the nation! (aſide.)

div.stage: (They both draw chairs, and ſit looking at one another, waiting for each to begin.)

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Be brief—my good friend, be brief!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Brief—why we hav'nt begun yet.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Then why the devil don't we? How long am I to wait, before the mighty matter is brought upon the carpet? Do you conſider that I am on the point of being married, Sir?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, what would you be at?

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: I be at—I want to know what you would be at.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,—why this is the ſtrangeſt thing! to ſee an old fellow, high in the ſtate, the night he ſhould be married, forſake his bride, and come with a train arm'd cap-à-piè, to diſturb another old fellow, and aſk him what he would be at! What's your buſineſs once more?

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: My buſineſs, with whom?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: With me, Sir—with me! What the devil do you do here?

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: That's what I want to know, Sir, and you'd beſt be quick in the relation! You ſeem to think time of no more value to me than ſtraw.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: (riſing) Ay, ſtraw—there it is! I thought he was mad; they never think of any thing but ſtraw. I am ſorry you are thus diſturbed, Don Gaſper.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: (Purſuing him) The diſturbance is nothing, if you would but come to the point— What is the plot—Where are the conſpirators, and what do they aim at?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Poor ſoul—poor ſoul! My dear friend you really ſhock me very much—tho' I knew your marriage was a mad action, I did not think it would have taken effect ſo ſoon.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Oons! this is beyond all bearing! (making a motion as tho' to his ſword, and ſeems diſappointed) no ſword—meet me to-morrow, Sir— meet me to-morrow!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: With all my heart. By that time you'll be in a ſtrait waiſtcoat, and I ſhall be ſafe. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: I am cooler. Such old men as we are can afford to waſte no blood—but there's your ring, Sir; and let that be the laſt token of good, or ill will, you ever ſend me. (Flinging the ring from him.)

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: My ring! (taking it from the floor) why, how came you—who gave you this ring? who gave it you?

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Why did not,—did not—oh, my mind miſgives me!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: You had it from your nephew—eh?

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Ye—y-e-s. (Trembling.)

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,—oh, a young rogue—oh, a plotting young villain! ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: What then I have—oh, ſhame to my years—I have been made a jeſt of.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: A jeſt—Heaven grant you may be made nothing worſe of! Hurry home my dear friend; you know what I ſaid to-day about your bride's odd fancies. Hurry home, and be thankful if it is a jeſt!

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: What do you imagine—do you conceive—oh, my dear, dear friend! But hold, you are in the plot—the ring is your's—you are in the plot! (Ragefully.)

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Believe me Don Gaſper—

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Oh, what a beetle, what a bat, I have been! but I'll repay your jeſt with intereſt. In the firſt place—and that's only for a beginning mind me, only for a beginning—my Octavio ſhall never marry your daughter. How d'ye like that jeſt? Oh what a blind—blind—oh! (Going off ſtamping.)

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
(going after him) My dear Don Gaſper, my friend, my worthy friend, I entreat—Zounds! he's gone! If it had not been for his choak-pear about Octavio, how I could laugh. Why, what the plague did that impertinent Don Julio take ſuch a liberty with my ring for? how dared he haul me head and ears into his ſcheme, to laugh at his worthy uncle? But zooks it is a good laugh
after all — ha, ha, ha—but if Gaſper now, thro' ſpite, ſhould prevent Octavio's marriage! What's to be done? hang me if I go to bed to night— I'll find out Octavio wherever he is, make him ſteal my daughter, conclude the marriage, and then I'll laugh with Julio, 'till my old ſides crack. Exit.

div.head: SCENE changes to the Street, before Don Gaſper's.
div.stage: He knocks gently at the door.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I dare not be louder; but ſure the ear of love can catch the gentleſt ſound!

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: (from the balcony) Oh, are you come, Sir—I'll call my lady down.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Oh haſte! the minutes fly; I have ſecur'd a ſafe retreat—leave all behind, and bring Antonia only to my arms. (A noiſe of people advancing) Hah! what noiſe is that? and lights too! they come this way—ſurely 'tis Don Gaſper's voice—I am breathleſs with my fears.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: (without) Put out your lights—extinguiſh your torches, and be ſilent.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis he—ſhall I plunge this ſword into his boſom, or my own? oh, either way I'm loſt! (Don Gaſper enters, and knocks loudly.)

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I'll be a match for his great grandſires, ring, truſt me! (Knocks again.)

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: (from the balcony) We are juſt ready, Sir—have a moment's patience.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p:
Juſt ready for what? Oh I am arrived in the very nick of ſome curſed ſcheme! Keep your ſwords drawn. (to his ſervants) Come, I'll not give
way to ſuſpicions—ſhe ſhall have fair play—appearances may deceive.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Hah! by Heaven, Antonia — we are ruin'd!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Where are you, my beſt wiſhes? lord of my vows, and charmer of my ſoul, where are you?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Oh heavens! (half drawing his ſword.)

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Well, well, that may be all meant for me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Give me your hand, my love, my life, and guide me to your boſom—the home for which I pant!

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Hum—that is rather too much, too! I'm afraid that's too ſweet a morſel to be meant for my chops.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: (groping about) Oh, are you here indeed? you frighten'd me with your ſilence. Here take theſe jewels, and let us haſte away.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: H-a-h, are you thereabouts, madam? (between his teeth) then I'm cozen'd.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: (aſide) To attempt to force her off would be in vain.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Will you not ſpeak? do you repent already? before poſſeſſion are you cold, and falſe?

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Before —ah, ah! —well that's great comfort. Whatever is deſign'd, I am beforehand with the miſchief, however.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Am I not to be your wife?—this very day did we not invoke Heaven to bleſs our vows?

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Now then 'tis clearly me, and I'll be mute no longer.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Oh Henry! Henry! (mournfully.)

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: (ſtarting) Who doſt thou take me for— Henry? Oh thou perfidious wretch!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Don Gaſper—what will become of me? Why—why are you ſo angry, Sir, at my naming one who in the cold grave cannot rival you? I was only going to ſay, that Henry would not have been ſo unkindly ſilent.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Was that all indeed, my little Tony? but 'twas wrong to think upon a young man. Never let your thoughts run upon a young man, whether in a grave, or a garret.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Never, Sir, be aſſured. Neither in one place, or the other, will my thoughts ever ſeek a lover. But why did you not ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Faith, you prattled love ſo prettily, I could have heard your little tongue run for ever. But how came you out ſo late, and with theſe jewels, and parcels?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Sir!—I was—why Sir—

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, we thought the city was in arms, and pack'd up our things to ſecure 'em. Lord, Sir, we were ſo ſcared! about plots, and robberies, and—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, terrified to death.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Oh it's all quell'd now—'tis all over, my pretty chuck. As ſoon as I appear'd amongſt 'em, and threaten'd 'em, and harangued 'em on their duty, they were as ſilent as the ſoft tread of a thief on a dark ſtair-caſe. I am reſolv'd ſhe ſhan't know what a gull I was. (aſide) Come now let's in, and join our tender hearts in one.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir. Day is on the point of breaking—dear welcome day! and I am reſolv'd to paſs it unbound by any vows, but thoſe of love.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: In this one point, Sir, I muſt govern, or here I vow moſt ſolemnly, never to be yours.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Oh its a raſh vow—a moſt unjuſtifiable vow!

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Not ſo raſh a vow as that you want her to make.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: What's that, minx?

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Why Sir, with ſubmiſſion, I ſay its moſt raſh and unjuſtifiable, for eighteen to riſe out of bed, and go to church, to vow to love ſixty-five— and I'll maintain it.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: But the vow was made, huſſey, and all vows muſt be kept—religiouſly kept! and therefore, though it goes againſt me, even this laſt ſhall be kept. So come in, my little Tony, and learn of your nown Hubby, never to break a vow.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: That ſecures me! Her delicacy is ſafe from inſult, and when I ſee her next, it ſhall be with powers to ſuppreſs his audacious, fancied rights, and cloſe the neceſſity for theſe degrading acts for ever. Exit.

div.head: SCENE changes to Don Alexis's Garden.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Gad I am glad I found ye—'twas deviliſh lucky! Viola is certainly ſomewhere in the garden—both my wife and Carlota aſſured me that ſhe was.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: And the ladder of ropes is ſuſpended from the place you pointed out.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Exactly there—I help'd to fix it myſelf— 'tis very ſecure.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: The dear little madcap muſt have her way; but 'tis ſtrange ſhe prefers ſcaling a wall at midnight, to walking quietly thro' the gate in the ſunſhine. Hiſt!—I hear the tread of gentle feet.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Then I'm off. If ſhe ſhould find us together, the perverſe baggage would ſuſpect our intelligence, and that would ſpoil all—ſo I'm off! (lowering his voice.) Exit.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: In a few hours, expect us at your feet aſking pardon and bleſſing. (A pauſe.) Charming Viola, appear! I hear you not; yet by the ſoft influence about me, I am ſure you are near. What delightful faculty is this, which allows us to be conſcious of the preſence of the object we adore, without the vulgar intervention of the ſenſes?— It muſt be the privilege of pureſt love!

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: (entering.) The privilege of fancy— all mere fancy; tho' you would exalt it into a faculty!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Hah, my charmer! (catching her in his arms) faculties, and fancies, are now equally nothing;—all loſt in tranſport, at finding thee in my arms.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: I proteſt I begin to believe you very dangerous. I inſiſt on your quitting me this inſtant. (breaking from him) Heavens what a ſituation! in the arms of a man—alone—in a garden, at two o'clock in the morning? (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: What doſt think of, ſweet angel?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: That the ſooner we are out of this place the better.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Suppoſe I ſecure her mine! I almoſt fear ſome new caprice—and if I miſtake not, her little heart flutters at this moment, in uniſon with my own. Dear bewitching woman, let me once more taſte—

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Hold, Sir! or by all that's good— (breaking from him) I never knew till now what reſiſtance meant. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: By heavens I will not loſe this charming moment!

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Then you loſe me for ever—make your election!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: This moment is preſented to us by love —let us prove ourſelves worthy of the boon!

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: How? by diſgracing love?

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: We'll argue that point hereafter; but now—

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Hold, Sir—I am neither blind to your intention, nor to my own danger—but know you are meditating an irremediable crime!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: How irremediable? Love itſelf ſhall remedy the crimes it makes.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Hah! you know not what you ſpeak of, nor can I explain myſelf—but let us fly!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Then we will fly my little trembler, and Hymen ſhall—

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Yet ſtay—I cannot go with you alone —you muſt conſent that a lady accompanies us.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: No matter. You muſt promiſe me, without aſking queſtions, to conduct her ſafely to Don Sebaſtian; and then to conduct me in ſafety to your father's.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: To my ghoſtly father you mean—to a prieſt?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: No, to Don Gaſper—on thoſe terms I ſcale the wall with you, and on no other.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: It is odd, and myſterious; but I'll ſcale walls with you on any terms. Where is the lady?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p:
We ſhall find her in the next walk— oh, no, ſhe is haſt'ning hither. (Enter Viola, veil'd.) Come fair damſel, this is the valourous knight who is to conduct us thro' all the intervening dragons, and giants, to the quiet and ſober
pale of matrimony—where we ſhall grow good, and ſtupid: (drawling) and recollect the kind action of this night, with matronly thankfulneſs and decency.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: (Aſide.) 'Tis a vile thought, and ſticks moſt indigeſtibly! Why muſt love be thus ſhackled? I feel I ſhall repent, and leap the pale;—but I am fairly caught now, and muſt ſubmit. Come my little fawns! take each an arm.—Egad, let us make haſte, or ſome unlucky ideas, which are growing rather ponderous, will prevent my flight over the wall!

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: I'll be hang'd if it is not the idea of matrimony you find ſo heavy!—but be of good comfort, Signor, and make ſpeed—your fate has prepared a conſolation you little expect. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Well, day at laſt is broad awake; and the vile night, which cloaks ſo many ſchemes, and villainous plots, againſt the peace of wary huſbands, is paſs'd away—and all hath gone well! yes, all hath gone well, except with my poor aching bones, and ſleepleſs eyes. Spent all theſe hours upon a mat at Antonia's chamber door—dared not leave it. Truly ſhe is a treaſure, but if to ſecure it I muſt fag out the remnant of my life in theſe alarms, and fears, and miſgivings.—Well, well, 'tis too late now to think about that; my hour is come! (Dolefully.)

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Don Octavio, and a lady, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p:
Permit me, Sir, to aſk your protection
for this lady for a few hours;—if you knew her, you would think ſhe had a right to claim it.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: To claim it—why, who is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: That I am forbid to tell—do you releaſe me from my promiſe, madam?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: No, certainly;—and yet if I did, it were much the ſame thing, for you do not know me.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Not know the lady!

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Believe me he does not; and yet if you aſk him, he'll ſwear he does.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Surely, tho' you are veil'd, I can ſwear you are the ſame ſweet melting creature, who in a certain garden—

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Found herſelf in your arms; and afterwards leapt the wall with you—that you may ſafely ſwear.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Yet I know you not—ha, ha, ha, permit me (apart) —Perhaps you'll deny being her, whom I am to marry to day?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Oh, no—I ſwear I will marry you to day, if Don Alexis gives conſent.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: We have more than his conſent—his ardent wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Yet I ſhall not be your's.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Why, what a ſweet enigmatical charmer you are!

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: (to Don Gaſper) If I miſtake not, Sir, this houſe has a miſtreſs—may I be permitted to wait on Donna Antonia?

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Madam—ma—Octavio! (Whiſpers.)

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Oh yes, of rank and reputation—but a little capricious.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p:
Pardon me, madam! I will wait on you
to Antonia's apartment.—I ſhan't care to leave them together tho'! (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: What can ſhe mean with her riddle-merees? I am perplex'd (Sebaſtian enters with Viola.) Hah Don Sebaſtian! What the weighty ceremony ſo lightly over? Madam, I wiſh you all the joys which belong to your new ſtate. Dear Sebaſtian (taking him aſide) tell me—how doſt feel?

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p: Feel!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Ay;—in a few hours I ſhall be in the ſame claſs, and I want to gueſs how it is.

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p: If you love as I do, you'll feel as I do—bleſt!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: I fear all you married rogues are ſo many decoy ducks; you look up with envy, and cry quake, quake, to your fellows at large; and when you have coax'd us into the ſnare, clap your wings, and exult.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: (running to Sebaſtian.) Oh, I hear my father's voice—I would not have him ſee you at this inſtant. (Apart.) Pardon my freedom Don Octavio, but it will be infinitely kind if you'll both leave me.

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p: Thoſe fears are idle my charmer—the moment muſt arrive.

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Nay, do not ſtay to argue, but oblige me!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: What, Sir, ſo much of a huſband in half an hour, as to diſpute a command? I'll take him to taſk, madam, and give him a leſſon on obedience. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Alexis.
sp.p: (without) Octavio, and a lady veil'd? (entering) then all is right! Hah Viola! well, tell me, is it all over—are you married?

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—enough ſaid! ha, ha, ha,—now I can laugh at Gaſper, and enjoy Don Julio's joke—ha, ha, ha—and you too—you have been finely nick'd—I have been oblig'd to cheat you into marrying the man you liked—ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, forgive what I have done!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Forgive thee, my girl! ay that I will— here's my hand upon't.—Hah Don Gaſper! (he enters) your moſt obedient very humble ſervant! How do you find yourſelf after your laſt night's whim, Sir?—My ſeal-ring is at your ſervice, at any time, Don Gaſper—ha, ha, ha,—two jokes at once—I ſhall laugh now, 'till I am a grandfather.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: If you laugh till my Octavio makes you a grandfather, it will be a very long fit I promiſe ye.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Dye think ſo? I'll truſt him!

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: He is now in the next room, at the feet of a young lady, whoſe charms are ſufficient, I truſt, to blot thoſe of your daughter from his heart.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: What's that? Octavio at the feet of a lady! d'ye hear that, Viola?

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Your daughter—Pardon me, fair lady!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, and your daughter too—your daughter! Let me ſee your encourage her huſband to kneel to other women in your houſe.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Her huſband—ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Zounds, Sir, this is no laughing matter —how dare you, Sir—Why, Viola, why don't you rave and ſtorm, as women do on theſe occaſions?

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Alas, Sir! I have no right.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: No right! I ſhall ſee that. Here Don Octavio, I ſay! The very day of his marriage— nay within the hour! (Enter Octavio.)

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Don Alexis—your pleaſure?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: My pleaſure, Sir, is, that—Zounds!— that your pleaſure ſhall be with my daughter.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: 'Tis very kind—nothing can make me ſo happy.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Then what the devil do you mean by— by—your father ſays you were at the feet of a lady.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: I was.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: You was!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Why ſhould that offend you? Do you not wiſh me to love your daughter?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Love my daughter, and kneel to another!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: All miſtake, Sir—another! I'll convince you that Viola alone (going to the wing) here ſhe comes! the dear lively girl! who leapt a garden wall, to give a ſober marriage the air of a romance.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Oons! where am I? are not you my daughter? (twitching off Viola's veil) yes. Did you not leap the wall with him?

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: And are you not married?

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: I am indeed! (curtſeying.)

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: And did you, Madam, leap a wall?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: And are you married too?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: I am, indeed! (throws up her veil, and curtſeys.)

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: My wife—Oons—my wife!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Amazement! his wife!

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: His wife leap the wall with my Octavio —ha, ha, ha. I'll add another five hundred moidores to your yearly allowance, for that my boy! Prithee, dear Don, indulge your laugh; you were in a very fine vein a minute ago—ha, ha, ha— now laugh till you're a grandfather!

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Don Octavio, I have uſed you ill; but I truſt your generoſity will pardon my taking advantage of your partiality for me, to ſerve two amiable and faithful lovers.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: You have uſed me ill, indeed! yet hang it, come, I am not married—I am not married however! (aſide) Yes, Madam, I can forgive you; but how ſhall I forgive myſelf? I had you—oh, diſtraction! I had you alone—amidſt the conſcious ſhades of night—and in my power!

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir! no woman can be alone, nor in the power of any man, whilſt ſhe reſpects herſelf, and is guarded by a ſenſe of her duty. You ſee, Don Alexis, what benefits ariſe from plotting without a woman. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Oh, I ſhall be mad! ſo it was my wife, then, to whom you were kneeling? and it was you whom I preſs'd yeſterday to grant him ſome ſmall favours?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Juſt ſo, my ſweet Hubby!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Come, be merry, old Gentleman.—A companion for your ſeal ring—two jokes at once, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Ay, you have it all to nothing now. And you have the impudence to love my wife? (to Octavio.)

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: More than ever, now there's no danger of matrimony.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: And you are now conſidering when you ſhall make me a — a ſatyr, eh? come, be frank— when is it to be?

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Faith, I wiſh I could tell.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: I will anſwer for him!—it ſhall be never; whilſt you repoſe a generous confidence in me, and allow me to be the guardian of my own honour. (Don Gaſp. goes out.)

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: Now I intreat you, my dear Don Alexis, be a very tyrant! ſuſpect her, watch her, and confine her—will you be ſo much my friend?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I don't know what I ſhall be yet;—both as huſband and father, I have ingeniouſly contrived to bite myſelf moſt d—n—bly! As for you, Madam, (to Viola) bread and water, and a dark chamber, ſhall be your lot—

sp.speaker: Sebaſ.
sp.p: (entering) No, Sir,—I am the arbiter of her lot;—however, I confirm half your puniſhment; and a dark chamber ſhe ſhall certainly have This is the expreſſion, I am told, which had nearly prov'd fatal to the Comedy. I ſhould not have printed it, but from the reſolution I have religiouſly kept, of reſtoring every thing that was objected to..

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: What then, thou art really married—and married to Sebaſtian!

sp.speaker: Viola.
sp.p: Dear, Sir, you aſſured me, that of the two fools you preferred him.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Yes, but I depended on your perverſeneſs, huſſey?

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: (Leading in Antonia) Come, you, who have not ſeen my little pet, behold her—Nay, I preſent her to ye all, as the pattern of meekneſs and perfect love—Oh its a ſweet pudſey.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Meekneſs, alas! you ſhould not anſwer for; you know I am a woman. My perfect love, indeed you may—the world has not a heart ſo truly wedded as Antonia's—behold its maſter— its lawful lord, my huſband! (Pointing to the oppoſite door.)

sp.speaker: Don Henry.
sp.p: (entering) Come, my Antonia, to his arms! Yes, I am thy huſband —now I ſtand boldly forward, and proclaim my title—I am thy huſband! that dear diſtinction which heaven has bleſt me with, heaven only ſhall reclaim!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.p: What! am I to loſe my mother as well as my wife?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: (To Gaſp.) Your nephew! why is this full moon? We are all going to run out of our wits.

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Don't be diſhearten'd—tho' it ſhould be ſo—You'll not have far to run!

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Why Julio, what in the name of—

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: No, Sir—not Julio, but Don Henry. That Don Henry whom you ſo baſely reported to be dead; that you might diſhonour him in ſecurity.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: How!—why—why you are dead—as good as dead; you are dead in law—you are outlaw'd, baniſh'd—

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: No, Sir, neither—reſtored to my country! Behold my pardon! (Shews a paper.)

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Your pardon!—hum! Now, then I ſee the whole;—I muſt be telling my ſecrets, with a devil to it! Well you got it through me you know—you may thank the muſic of my moidores for that dance!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: No, Sir! (throwing down a purſe) there is the gold you baſely barter'd for the pardon you ſolicited. My pardon I obtain'd from the hands of majeſty itſelf—from our gracious queen! Oh, when her kingdom's foes provoke correction from her ſubjects arms, then ſhall my ſword again be drawn, nor aſk forgiveneſs for its ardent duty!

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Well, very well—but what has your pardon to do with my wife? (putting her behind him) What have you to do with Tony?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: She is my wife; made mine by contract, before you deſtin'd her the bliſs of being your's. Pardon me then, my ſweet Antonia! (taking her from Gaſper) if I deprive you of his venerable charmer, and give you in his place a huſband!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Hum! hum! (Sings.)
sp.l: Once I was a merry old man,
But now the caſe is chang'd!
sp.p: Who could have thought that my old ſeal ring would ever have been a taliſman to make lovers happy, and ſave a Greybeard from folly?

sp.speaker: Seraph.
sp.p: Come Don Gaſper, let me adviſe you to think your loſs a gain—you ſee in your humble ſervant, what miſchievous creatures young wives are;—ſhe'd plague your heart out, as I do my old huſband's.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Faith ſhe ſays true. A minute ago I thought the laugh on my ſide; but 'tis ſtill on your own. You have loſt a young wife, and I have found one.

sp.speaker: Gaſp.
sp.p: Why, to ſay truth, if it were not that at preſent I feel a little aukward, and don't know very well which way to look.—As to your contract I might perhaps diſpute its powers, but as here is a ſtroke or two of mine, which may be, I ſhan't be ſorry to have drop'd, e'en go to church i'gad's name; and when ye come home beware of plots and ſcal rings!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: This is generous! The ſentiments you profeſs'd for me I ſee will be converted to a more decent regard, and we ſhall all be united in the bands of charming friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Gad this looks like a ſort of general amneſty—ſo let the frolick go round! But dare my faults hope forgiveneſs here? (to the houſe) Yes;—I am on this ſpot an old offender; and have ſo often gratefully experienced the candour of my judges, that I truſt now to meet their pardon — and invoke the gracious ſign!

div.head: EPILOGUE,
div.l: A Mourning Bride!—that wou'd be ſomething new—
(That I'm a Mourning Huſband is too true,
Cries old Sir Teſty in his gouty chair,)
"Ah could I wedlock's fatal ſlip repair!
"But young wives are a ſort of flying gout,
"Torments for which no cure was e'er found out;
"Both old men's plagues, to puniſh youthful tricks,
"Equally difficult, I fear, to fix.
"Of wife and gout alike I ſtand in dread,
"For both, alas! ſometimes affect the head."
Thus rail old cynics, ſtriving to diſparage
The charming ſilken ties of modern marriage.
In former times, when folks agreed to wed,
The ſilent bride by ſilent bridegroom led,
Up to the altar march'd in ſolemn ſtate,
All was demure, and ſtupidly ſedate.
Impreſs'd with awe, while neither dar'd to ſpeak,
A wedding was a mere Ballet Tragique.
Thank Heav'n we're paſt the ages of romance;
Wedlock is now a kind of country dance,
Where man and wife with ſmiles each other greet,
Take hands, change ſides, and part as ſoon as meet;
Pleaſure's ſoft accents ev'ry care diſpel,
While Hymen fiddles Vive la Bagatelle.
Bleſt age! when ceremony's chains are worn,
Like bracelets, not to ſetter, but adorn.
When we aſſume deep mourning's fable ſhew,
'Tis etiquette preſcribes the form of woe:
Whate'er our loſs, we muſt have faſhion's leave,
Ere we can venture decently to grieve.
Blameleſs the heir o'er the dear parchment chuckles,
If he's unpowder'd, and puts on black buckles,
Till the grey frock ſpeaks his firſt anguiſh o'er,
And he's but half as wretched as before.
Ere the gay widow firſt abroad is ſeen,
Deck'd in exhilarating bombazeen,
While the dear Col'nel viſits unſuſpected,
And ſhe's as well as could have been expected;
Cuſtom's indulgence wiſely does ſhe borrow,
In cards of compliments exhauſts her ſorrow;
Of tears her black-edg'd paper fills the place,
Mourns as her proxy, and preſerves her face.
Our Mourning Bride, who with no ſorrow labours,
And mourns but in appearance, like her neighbours,
Tho' forc'd by etiquette, good humour loves, as well as any here,
Bleſt in the fate which theſe kind ſmiles decree her,
She hopes her friends will often come to ſee her.
